stream_context.summary: Kaze brings N64 programmer Sauraen on a live call to diagnose why Sauraen’s F3DEX3 microcode (meant to add new graphics features and reduce RDP time) is running slower in Return to Yoshi’s Island than expected. They A/B test old F3DEX3 vs F3DEX2 vs current F3DEX3 on real hardware, disable lighting to isolate costs, and then modify microcode instrumentation to split RSP time into vertex-processing and triangle-processing cycle counters. Results suggest the slowdown is not solely vertex processing; there appears to be ~8–9 ms of additional RSP time unaccounted for by vertex+triangle processing, prompting further profiling plans. After the call, Kaze returns to level work on a Mario Kart 64 “retro pipe” stage (Calamari Desert-inspired), discussing design beats like a timed race, moving train hazards, and visual tweaks.
stream_context.significance_reason: Rare stream centered on a deep collaboration with Sauraen, including real-time performance experiments, new microcode profiling instrumentation added specifically for RTYI, and a concrete reframing of the bottleneck (unexplained RSP overhead beyond vertex/triangle work).

findings.summary: Sauraen frames F3DEX3’s intent as a trade: faster RDP (more features + reduced RDP time) at the cost of higher RSP time; RTYI may uniquely expose this because its RDP side is already efficient, making RSP the new bottleneck.

Kaze reports expecting roughly a 5–15% speedup from F3DEX3 overall, but real N64 profiling shows the opposite in his build: baseline old F3DEX3 shows ~21.7 ms GFX time; current F3DEX3 shows ~27 ms in the same scene, indicating a major regression or measurement mismatch.

RTYI does not plan to use point lights (compatibility/emulator concerns and art style): environments are vertex-colored, and light “glows” are faked via CPU-updated vertex colors; only actors use lighting, and Kaze can have up to ~7 runtime-computed directional lights active in a level.

They test by disabling all microcode lighting (commenting out lighting entry) and see only ~2 ms improvement, implying lighting cost alone cannot explain the jump from ~25.5 ms to ~27 ms and the broader regression being investigated.

Sauraen and Kaze add new microcode performance instrumentation: replacing prior footer counters with two U32 counters for vertex-processing cycles and triangle-processing cycles (RCP cycles), requiring Kaze to update his in-game profiler display and conversion (divide by ~62).

With the new counters working, Kaze observes about ~10 ms vertex time and ~8 ms triangle time (≈18 ms total), but the total RSP task is still ~27 ms—leaving an unexplained ~8–9 ms overhead not attributable to vertex+triangle processing, suggesting additional hidden costs (misc commands/overlay switching/stalls/tooling mismatch) that need further profiling.

Sauraen proposes a potential bespoke “F3DEX2.5” direction for RTYI: keep F3DEX3’s improvements/features but backport parts of F3DEX2’s vertex/lighting pipeline if RTYI doesn’t need point lights, aiming to recover RSP performance while retaining key upgrades.

Kaze explains a recurring RTYI motif: each level includes a “retro pipe” referencing a pre-end-of-N64-era game; for Course 12, the pipe shows Mario Kart 64 footage/imagery (a playful inversion of MK64 containing a Mario 64 course).

Course 12’s retro segment is shaping into a timed race (~40–45 seconds) with a start/finish line, planned moving train elements (including smoke particles), and added hazards like cacti; Kaze also considers how the train interacts with a tunnel shortcut to balance risk/reward.

Kaze recounts seeing N64 repro carts with ROM hacks (including ones he worked on) being sold at events/stores; he notes the uneasy reality that money goes to resellers exploiting creators’ work, and Sauraen mentions seeing stores with very large aggregate sales of such carts.

Explains architectural differences between F3DEX2 and F3DEX3: F3DEX3 does more per-vertex work (model→world and world→clip transforms, normal transforms + normalization, optional octahedral normals) to enable features and make point lighting scale better; F3DEX2 can be faster for basic directional lighting by transforming lights into model space per bone and doing only model→clip per vertex.

Leads the investigation plan: establish baseline timings, isolate costs by disabling lighting, then add new cycle-based counters for vertex and triangle processing to locate where the missing time is coming from.

Provides practical build/tooling support: offers a SummerCart64 as a faster development workflow option, and instructs Kaze to enable additional profiling via Makefile flags (e.g., command count / clock sampling).

Introduces himself on-stream with credentials (F3DEX3 author; Triforce% director; Sec64 author; long-time OoT music modder), giving documentary-useful provenance for why he’s a key external technical collaborator.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Ideally, I wouldn’t have to deal with emulators at all. I just want to make my N64 game.
memorable_quotes.context: Sums up the team’s goal of building something ambitious on real hardware constraints, and the friction of emulator variance while developing a decomp-based ROM hack.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: All graphics are just about faking it, right?
memorable_quotes.context: Said while discussing “glow effects” vs. vertex-color fakes; captures the project’s practical art/tech philosophy on N64-era rendering.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I saw in one of the vendor booths they had a bunch of N64 repro carts with ROM hacks on... that money is going to somebody who is just taking our stuff and selling it.
memorable_quotes.context: A candid moment about the uncomfortable economics of ROM hack distribution and third-party profiteering.

key_stories.title: Diagnosing why F3DEX3 is slower in RTYI
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Sauraen suspect RTYI’s strong RDP efficiency makes RSP costs more visible, causing F3DEX3’s extra vertex/feature overhead to become a bottleneck. Live tests (old F3DEX3 vs F3DEX2 vs current F3DEX3) plus disabling lighting don’t fully explain the regression, so they add new microcode counters to split vertex and triangle processing time.
key_stories.challenge: F3DEX3 was expected to speed RTYI up, but measured GFX/RSP timings in Kaze’s build were significantly worse and inconsistent across baselines.
key_stories.process: They establish baselines, attempt to isolate lighting cost, then modify microcode and the yield footer to record vertex and triangle processing cycles and add additional command-count profiling via Makefile flags.
key_stories.outcome: New instrumentation reveals ~18 ms of vertex+triangle processing but ~27 ms total RSP time, leaving ~8–9 ms unexplained; Sauraen plans further investigation and suggests a possible “F3DEX2.5” hybrid approach for RTYI.
key_stories.key_quote: We have 10 milliseconds for vertices, 8 milliseconds for triangles, and 27 milliseconds… so it’s not just that the vertex processing is slower.

key_stories.title: Seeing ROM hacks sold as repro carts
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes encountering physical repro cartridges of ROM hacks for sale at an event/vendor booth, including a hack he worked on. Both he and Sauraen acknowledge that widespread resale happens at scale, and creators often have to tolerate it as part of being in the scene.
key_stories.challenge: Third parties monetize ROM hacks without compensating creators, raising ethical and practical concerns for a project like RTYI.
key_stories.process: Kaze recounts the incident and reflects on the reality of the ecosystem; Sauraen adds that some stores appear to have very large aggregate sales across many hacks.
key_stories.outcome: No solution is implemented here, but it’s flagged as a recurring issue the team is aware of while building a high-profile hack.
key_stories.key_quote: You gotta have some tolerance for that in order to be in this.

open_questions.topic: Unexplained ~8–9 ms RSP overhead in current F3DEX3 profiling
open_questions.context: New counters suggest vertex (~10 ms) + triangle (~8 ms) processing does not sum to the total RSP task time (~27 ms), leaving substantial time unattributed.
questions: What specific categories of work fill the missing ~8–9 ms (overlay swaps, matrix loads, command shuttling, stalls, cache/DMEM effects, FIFO waits, or something else)?
Does RTYI’s display-list structure (command patterns, state changes, or buffer sizes) interact poorly with F3DEX3 compared to OoT scenes Sauraen profiled?
Did any recent RTYI-side changes (GBI usage, actor lighting, vertex formats, DMA patterns) coincide with the jump from ~25.5 ms to ~27 ms baseline?
What additional counters or traces can Sauraen add next (e.g., per-command-class timing, overlay swap counts, DMA wait cycles) to isolate the overhead definitively?

open_questions.topic: Potential ‘F3DEX2.5’ hybrid microcode path for RTYI
open_questions.context: Sauraen floated building a version that keeps F3DEX3’s benefits but backports F3DEX2’s faster directional-lighting/vertex pipeline, since RTYI avoids point lights.
questions: Which F3DEX3 features are non-negotiable for RTYI (e.g., cel shading, AO/occlusion plane, larger vertex buffer), and which can be dropped to regain RSP headroom?
What’s the minimal subset of F3DEX3 architectural changes that must remain to support RTYI’s current art/engine pipeline?
How would a hybrid microcode affect content creation (vertex formats, normals, lighting authoring, compatibility with existing assets)?

open_questions.topic: Lighting strategy: up to seven directional lights, but vertex-colored environments
open_questions.context: Kaze states environments are vertex-colored and he fakes point lights via CPU-updated vertex colors; actors use world lighting, and some levels can compute multiple directional lights at runtime.
questions: How are up to seven directional lights combined (max, additive, weighted, nearest-N, time-sliced), and what drove that choice artistically and technically?
What does ‘compute at runtime’ mean here—are directions derived from scene objects (sun position, fire, etc.) and how often are they updated?
What are the exact constraints that make point lights undesirable (emulator correctness, performance, artistic mismatch), and were there any experiments that failed?

open_questions.topic: Handling physical repro-cart resale of ROM hacks
open_questions.context: Kaze and Sauraen note third parties sell hacks on cartridges, sometimes at large scale, with no compensation to creators.
questions: Has the RTYI team discussed any ‘official’ physical release approach (or explicit non-release) to reduce gray-market demand, or is that out of scope?
What was Kaze’s reaction when he first saw a cart of a hack he worked on being sold—did it change how he thinks about distribution/branding/credits?
Are there technical measures being considered (boot code, signatures, messaging) to discourage resellers, and do they actually work in practice?
